treatments.title: Red Light Therapy
treatments.description: Low-level red and near-infrared light applied to skin to stimulate cellular repair and reduce inflammation. Commonly used for wound healing, pain reduction, and improving tissue recovery.
details: How it works: photons absorbed by mitochondria increase ATP production and modulate inflammation.
Benefits: reduced pain, faster healing, improved circulation.
Typical session: 5–20 minutes depending on device intensity and treatment area.
Precautions: avoid direct eye exposure; consult if pregnant or on photosensitizing medication.

treatments.title: Stretching
treatments.description: Targeted stretches improve flexibility, range of motion, and muscle balance. Used to prevent injury, relieve tightness, and support rehabilitation.
details: Types: static, dynamic, and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF).
Benefits: increased mobility, reduced muscle tension, better posture.
How to: hold static stretches 15–60 seconds; use controlled movement for dynamic stretches.
Precautions: avoid forcing a stretch through sharp pain; warm up before intense stretching.

treatments.title: Therapeutic Exercise
treatments.description: Individualized exercise programs to restore strength, coordination, and functional movement patterns. Exercises progress from basic activation to functional and sport-specific tasks.
details: Benefits: increased strength, endurance, functional independence, and injury prevention.
Components: mobility, stability, strength, cardiovascular, and neuromuscular retraining.
Typical plan: frequency and intensity tailored to condition and stage of recovery.
Precautions: follow professional guidance to avoid overload and improper form.

treatments.title: Electrical Stimulation (E-Stim)
treatments.description: Therapeutic electrical currents applied through the skin to reduce pain, promote muscle activation, and support tissue healing.
details: Modes: TENS for pain control, NMES for muscle re-education, IFC for deep tissue stimulation.
Benefits: immediate pain relief, improved muscle recruitment, reduced swelling in some cases.
How it's used: electrodes placed over target muscles or nerves; intensity adjusted to comfort and therapeutic goals.
Precautions: not for use over pacemakers, carotid sinus, pregnant abdomen, or open wounds without guidance.

treatments.title: Gua Sha & ASTYM
treatments.description: Manual and instrument-assisted techniques that address soft-tissue restrictions and scar tissue to improve mobility and reduce pain.
details: Gua Sha: scraping with a smooth-edged tool to move stagnant tissue and increase circulation.
ASTYM: a structured, instrument-assisted protocol to promote remodeling of scar tissue and stimulate healing.
Benefits: improved tissue mobility, decreased pain, restoration of painless movement patterns.
Precautions: may cause temporary redness or soreness; consult provider for fragile skin, bleeding disorders, or anticoagulant use.

treatments.title: Massage Therapy
treatments.description: Hands-on manipulation of muscles and soft tissues to reduce pain, relieve tension, improve circulation, and promote relaxation and healing.
details: Types: Swedish (relaxation), deep tissue (chronic tension), sports (athletic recovery), and trigger point therapy.
Benefits: decreased muscle tightness, improved range of motion, enhanced circulation, reduced stress and pain.
Typical session: 30–90 minutes; therapist uses strokes, kneading, compression and targeted techniques depending on goals.
Precautions: avoid on deep vein thrombosis, fever, open wounds, recent fractures, or over areas with active infection; disclose pregnancy, implants, and medications to your provider.

treatments.title: Percussive Massage (Massage Gun)
treatments.description: Percussive therapy using a handheld device delivering rapid pulses to soft tissue to reduce muscle tension, improve circulation, and accelerate warm-up and recovery.
details: Uses: pre/post-workout warm-up and recovery, relieving localized muscle tightness and trigger points.
Benefits: increased blood flow, reduced soreness, improved tissue mobility, quicker warm-up.
How to: apply low-to-moderate pressure and move slowly across the muscle for 30–90 seconds per area; avoid bony prominences.

Precautions: avoid use over acute injuries, fractures, deep vein thrombosis, varicose veins, or areas with decreased sensation; consult a provider if pregnant or if you have implanted electronic devices.

treatments.title: Cupping Therapy
treatments.description: Suction-based therapy using cups to lift the skin and soft tissues, increasing circulation and releasing muscular and fascial restrictions.
details: How it works: negative pressure draws blood to the surface, promotes local circulation, and can help break up adhesions.
Benefits: reduced muscle tension, improved range of motion, faster recovery, and pain relief for some conditions.
Typical session: cups applied for 5–20 minutes; may use static or moving (gliding) techniques depending on goals.
Precautions: common temporary marks or bruising; avoid on open wounds, skin infections, areas of poor sensation, or suspected DVT; consult if pregnant or taking anticoagulants.

treatments.title: Balance Training (Multiple Sclerosis)
treatments.alt: Person doing balance exercise with therapist
treatments.description: Targeted balance and vestibular exercises to improve postural stability, coordination, and confidence in people with multiple sclerosis. Aims to reduce fall risk and maintain mobility despite sensory, motor, and fatigue-related challenges.
details: Goals: enhance static and dynamic balance, gait stability, and reactive stepping to reduce falls.
Typical exercises: seated and standing weight shifts, tandem and single-leg stance with support, dynamic reaching, obstacle navigation, and gaze-stability/vestibular drills.
Progression: begin with supported, short-duration sets; increase challenge by reducing support, adding cognitive dual-tasks, uneven surfaces, or functional reaching as tolerated.
Benefits: improved steadiness, safer mobility, greater confidence, and reduced fall incidence when practiced regularly.

Precautions: account for heat sensitivity and fatigue—use short, frequent sessions; ensure supervision during standing/stepping tasks; stop if dizziness, severe imbalance, or marked spasticity occurs.

treatments.title: Dry Needling
treatments.description: Insertion of thin, solid filiform needles into myofascial trigger points to reduce pain, release tight muscle bands, and restore normal function.
details: How it works: needles mechanically disrupt dysfunctional muscle fibers and stimulate local biochemical and neurological responses that promote pain modulation and tissue relaxation.
Benefits: reduced local and referred pain, improved range of motion, decreased muscle tension, and facilitation of rehabilitation exercises.
Typical session: brief needle insertions held or manipulated to elicit a twitch response; often combined with manual therapy and therapeutic exercise.

Precautions: performed by trained clinicians; not recommended for patients with bleeding disorders, on anticoagulants, active infection at the site, or severe needle phobia. May cause temporary soreness or minor bruising.
